Table 3 3X Θ(L1-M-L2) M-C1 M-I M-L1 M-L2 ΔG(3X-4X) G1 72.5 2.096 2.780 2.285 2.426 17.4 G2 86.2 2.117 2.780 2.286 2.416 12.5 G3 95.3 2.121 2.819 2.296 2.401 10.7 G4 97.1 2.130 2.836 2.305 2.473 13.2 Understanding the acrylates formation from CO2 and ethylene over Ni- and Pd-based catalysts: A DFT study on the effects of solvents, methyl halides, and ligands Youcai Zhu Software Investigation Writing – original draft Xing Guo Software Writing – review & editing Xinxin Ding Methodology Li Sun Validation Mingguo Zhang Software Zhen Liu Project administration Writing – review & editing ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China School of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China ⁎ Corresponding author. In this work, two methylation reaction pathways were investigated to explore the role of solvent and I− on the formation of methyl acrylate from coupling of CO2 and ethylene catalyzed by nickel and palladium catalysts in the presence of MeI. The stabilization of non-productive intermediates is inhibited in the gas phase as well as in low-polar solvents, which explains the requirement of high excess of MeI to obtain high yields of methyl acrylate. The energy barrier for M-O bond cleavage as well as the stability of the overall reaction intermediates is consistent with the corresponding halogen electron-donating ability. The different catalytic behaviors of various bidentate ligands on Ni- and Pd-based catalysts were systematically investigated, mainly including dmpe(1,2-bis(dimethylphosphino)ethane), tmeda(tetramethylethylenediamine), dppe(1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane), dcpe(1,2-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)ethane) and dtbpe(1,2-bis(di-tert-butylphosphino)ethane). The energy barrier of M-O bond cleavage increases with the enhancement of ligand steric hindrance in the O1 (ester sp3 O atom) attack mechanism, while the corresponding O2 (carboxylic sp2 O atom) attack mechanism shows an opposite trend. The energy barrier of β-H elimination in both catalytic systems is strongly related to the electron-donating ability of the diphosphine ligand substituents. The dcpp(1,3-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)propane) ligand shows relatively good performance for β-H elimination among all the investigated ligands in Pd-mediated system. In general, diphosphine ligands are superior to diamine ligands in Pd-mediated system in terms of efficiency. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Methyl acrylate M-O bond cleavage β-H elimination Diphosphine ligands 1 Introduction The continuous emission and accumulation of carbon dioxide is the main cause of global warming. The world had witnessed another surge of CO2 levels in 2019, breaking the critical threshold of 410 parts per million global annual average. This upward trend accelerates [1]. The development of CO2 for the production of organic chemicals has enormous industrial benefits worldwide, as CO2 is a cheap, non-toxic and abundantly available C1 building block [2–13]. There has been some success in converting carbon dioxide into certain chemical products, such as the production of salicylic acid, urea, cyclic carbonate and polycarbonate, et al. [14–16]. However, chemical reactions have so far consumed less than 1% of the total CO2 emission globally [17]. This is due to the fact that CO2 capture and storage is expensive, but the underlying reason is the chemical inertness of CO2 [18–20]. Throughout, the key to utilizing carbon dioxide is an effective activation to overcome its high thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness [21–23]. A very interesting and attractive example is the formation of acrylic acid/acrylate from CO2 and ethylene under moderate reaction conditions, which is called a “dream reaction”. In this case, CO2 contributes 62% of the organic molecular mass [24–26]. However, the synthesis of acrylic acid and its derivatives from CO2 and ethylene has so far been fraught with challenges [20,27]. In the late 1970s, Inoue achieved the first successful coupling reaction of CO2 and butadiene catalyzed by palladium-phosphine complexes, and a small amount of γ-lactone was generated [28,29]. Subsequently, pioneering studies were independently reported by Hoberg [30,31] and Carmona [32–34] that the coupling of CO2 and ethylene occurs at zero-valent transition metal centers including nickel, iron, tungsten and molybdenum. It has been reported that the reaction ends with dimeric (Mo) or monomeric (W) hydro-acrylate complexes without obtaining the desired acrylic acid as well as its derivatives [32,34], or that the five-membered nickelalactone is so stable that β-H elimination is hardly to occur [30,31]. The first successful cleavage of a rigid planar five-membered nickelalactone was realized by Fischer et al. [35] using the ‘right’ ligand bis(diphenylphosphino)methane (dppm), with a high degree of flexibility. However, due to the high bond dissociation energy of the M-O moieties in the acrylate intermediate, a large number of kinetic obstacles to the elimination of acrylic acid have not been overcome so far, which makes it difficult for acrylic acid to be released from metal-hydrido-acrylate species. Aresta et al. [36] used a palladium complex with a carboxylic acid group to bypass these kinetic barriers and release the alkyl acrylate for the first time, which shows that the release of alkyl acrylate is possible at room temperature, at least in palladium complexes. In 2010, Bruckmeier et al. [37] revised the catalytic cycle with addition of methylation reagent (path I, black circle, Scheme 1) for the synthesis of methyl acrylate, which has been widely discussed and supported by many researchers [25,38-42]. The first step of the reaction is the formation of a metallalactone by insertion of CO2 into any of the M-C bonds and the formation of a new C-C bond. The second step is to weaken and cleave the M-O bond in the metallalactone by attacking the carbonyl oxygen atom through electrophilic action. The catalytic cycle completes with the following β-H elimination and finally reductive elimination of HX to regenerate the M(0) species. This in situ methylation is the first reported strategy to both eliminate β-hydride and release acrylate, although the resulting yields are far from quantitative [37]. Subsequently, Kühn in 2011 showed that the ligand variation of nickelalactone had a significant effect on the yield of methyl acrylate [42]. They found that nickelalactone with chelated diamine or diphosphine could successfully undergo β-H elimination to produce methyl acrylate due to electronic and steric hindrance effects on the nickel center. Sautet also examined the effect of the ligand on production of methyl acrylate. They found that the option of ligands had a significant influence on side reactions [41]. Plessow et al. [40] reported the iodide ion is dissociated from CH3I, and forms an ion pair in the presence of the solvent. Then, the energy barrier of β-H elimination is lowered through formation of a β-agostic intermediate. Finally, the catalytic cycle can be completed by releasing HI compounds and acrylates proposed by Hendriksen et al. [24] (path II, red circle, Scheme 1). In 2013, the experimental results of Kühn supported the ring-opening of nickelalactone and palladalactone by an extensive screening of methylation reagents. The experiments showed that MeOTf was much more efficient in metallalactone ring-opening than any other methylation reagent, including methyl iodide [25,38–42]. It was also demonstrated that the palladalactone is readily cleaved by MeI and MeOTf to give the ester, which proves that the chosen method is universal and can be extended to other metals. However, no more detailed studies have been conducted so far to elucidate the catalytic differences between Pd- and Ni-based catalysts in the presence of MeI, not to mention the lack of relevant mechanistic studies on the Pd-based catalyst. To date, theoretical studies on methyl acrylate production have been conducted only for nickel catalysts in the presence of MeI, with only few ligand types. In the present work, we studied the coupling reaction of CO2 and ethylene in the presence of MeI for three main objectives: (i) explore the role of solvent and I− on the formation of methyl acrylate from CO2 and ethylene catalyzed by nickel and palladium catalysts in the presence of MeI; (ii) unravel the differences in the catalytic mechanism between palladium- and nickel-based catalysts; and (iii) explore the new ligands that may lead to the development of novel catalytic systems with balanced performance in terms of oxidative coupling, M-O bond cleavage, and subsequent β-hydride elimination. 2 Computational details All DFT calculations including geometry optimizations and frequency calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 program package [43]. Geometry optimizations and frequency calculations were first carried out at B3LYP/def2-SVP level in the gas phase. Then, the gas phase geometries were fully re-optimized without any constraint at the B3LYP/def2-SVP(SMD) level using toluene, dichloromethane and dimethylformamide as the solvent models, respectively [44–46]. Throughout, we have employed harmonic vibrational frequency calculations to confirm that the structures have been properly optimized. Intrinsic reaction coordination (IRC) calculations were performed to verify the connections between the transition state and the corresponding reactant and the product [47]. To refine the electronic energies, high-level single-point energy calculations were computed for all structures by using the meta-GGA exchange-correlation functional M06L in combination with the def2-TZVP basis set, as it allows to achieve high accuracy in the description of transition metal complexes and at the same time accounts for non-covalent interactions [48]. The D3 version of Grimme's dispersion (GD3) was incorporated into the geometry optimizations. All the relative energies throughout the paper are in kcal/mol and refer to Gibbs free energies with inclusion of the thermal contribution to the Gibbs free energy and the free energy of solvation. The steric hindrance maps of the intermediates were probed using Sambuca 2.0 developed by Falivene et al. [49,50]. 3 Result and discussion Based on the experimental evidence and theoretical analysis, the reaction mechanism of nickel(0)-mediated production of methyl acrylate from CO2 and ethylene has been reasonably established in the presence of MeI (Scheme 1) [24,25,37-42]. Interestingly, the palladium-mediated system showed equivalent performance to nickel-mediated system in the production of methyl acrylate [38,51–54]. Initially, a reaction system with dmpe as ligand in the gas phase was designed to study the mechanism of the nickel- and palladium-based catalyst in methyl acrylate formation. Then, the effects of solvent and methyl halides (MeX) on acrylate formation were systematically investigated. Finally, based on our mechanistic studies, a series of ligands are proposed to lower the energy barriers of two key steps: M-O bond cleavage [41] and β-H elimination [38]. These ligands are expected to exhibit relatively good performance for the overall methyl acrylate formation reaction. MeI Assisted Acrylate Formation: Gas-Phase Reaction Route. Fig. 1 shows the relative Gibbs free energies for the methyl acrylate formation over Pd- and Ni-based catalysts, respectively. The reaction starts from the metallalactone complex 1. The first step is to weaken and cleave the M-O bond in the metallalactone by attacking the carbonyl oxygen atom through electrophilic reaction [38,41]. The intermediate 6 could form an ion pair by detachment of the loosely bounded I− [40]. However, when iodide dissociates to form ion pairs, intermediate 6 is extremely unstable (ΔGNi = 74.3 kcal/mol, ΔGPd = 70.7 kcal/mol relative to 1) in the gas phase, implying the iodide ion detachment was thermodynamically unfavorable. As iodide ion transfer to the center of the metal in intermediate 2, occupying the apex of a square-based pyramid. The equatorial ligand has a robust interaction with the metal center and a weak interaction with the vertex iodide ion. A significant weakening of the M-O bond can be seen in intermediate 2. Taking the Ni-mediated system as an example, the Ni-O bond extends from 1.884 Å in intermediate 1 to 1.976 Å in intermediate 2 (Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Materials). In addition, the Pd-O bond distance of 2.036 Å is longer than that of 1.884 Å in Ni-O bond under gas phase conditions, as reported by our group previously [55]. Subsequently, oxygen transfer to the other vertex when I− occupies the equatorial plane, implying a full cleavage of the M−O bond to yield 3 [42]. The second step is β-H elimination starting from complexes 3 and 6, respectively. The intermediate 6 (ion pair) is formed by detachment of the loosely bounded iodide ion. For intermediate 3, the iodide ion is tightly attached to the metal center on the equatorial plane [40]. In the neutral system, with β-H transferring to the metal center, the iodide ion will return to the apex of a square-based pyramid. Then, methyl acrylate can be released from complex 4, forming the MLnHI complex 5. In contrast to the palladium-catalyzed system, the corresponding product 5 of the Ni-based system was settled 2.6 kcal/mol above the reference structure 1, implying the methyl acrylate formation was thermodynamically unfavorable for the nickel-catalyzed system. When the iodide ion is completely detached from the system, the β-H agostic interaction in intermediate 7 can effectively facilitate the β-H elimination. Taking the Ni-mediated system as an example, the C β −H β bond was stretched with the corresponding C β −H β and Ni−H β bond lengths of 1.191 and 1.671 Å, respectively (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary Materials). The intermediate 7 undergoes β-H elimination to form intermediate 8, where the β-H transfer from C β atom to the metal center. Afterward, the complex 9 was formed by the iodide ion binding to the dangling hydrogen atom close to the metal center [56]. Then, the elimination of HI gives the methyl acrylate complex 10 [24], although elimination of molecular HI is computed to be slightly endoergic (ΔGNi = 7.4 kcal/mol, ΔGPd = 2.0 kcal/mol relative to 1). MeI Assisted Acrylate Formation: The Effect of Solvents. Table S1 lists the relative Gibbs free energies for the methyl acrylate formation over Ni- and Pd-based catalysts in three different solvents: (i) toluene (dielectric constant ε = 2.37) [57], (ii) dichloromethane (ε = 8.93) [37], and (iii) dimethylformamide (ε = 37.22) [58]. Among these solvents, toluene is basically non-polar, while dichloromethane and dimethylformamide are two typical polar solvents. The relative Gibbs free energies in gas phase are also included for comparison (Fig. 2 ). We observed a direct correlation between the energy barrier of M-O cleavage and the solvent dielectric constant. The energy barrier of M-O cleavage and β-H elimination in the solution phase are calculated to be lower than that in the gas phase. Polar solvents can better stabilize the transition state than the non-polar solvents and be able to facilitate the formation of methyl acrylate. In general, the energy barrier of M-O cleavage decreases with increase of the dielectric constant of solvents in both nickel- and palladium-mediated systems, from 26.0 kcal/mol (Ni catalyst in the gas phase) to 22.6 kcal/mol (Ni catalyst in dimethylformamide), and 26.3 kcal/mol (Pd catalyst in the gas phase) to 19.6 kcal/mol (Pd catalyst in dimethylformamide), respectively. Similarly, as the dielectric constant increases, the β-H elimination energy barrier decreases accordingly in both catalytic systems. The solvent dichloromethane gives the lowest energy barrier for M-O bond cleavage than the other two solvents and the gas phase in the Ni-mediated systems (Table S1 in the Supplementary Materials). There is also a slight extension of the M-O bond length for intermediate 2 in polar solvents in comparison to the same bond length in the gas phase, which further stabilizes intermediate 2. (Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Materials). It is worth noting that in some intermediates the weakly bound I− detached from the metal center and led to the formation of an ion pair [41]. The nature of the solvent is of importance for I− detachment, especially for the formation of intermediate 6. As shown in Fig. 2, intermediate 6 is hard to form through the electrophilic reaction in the gas phase because of the inhibitive endergonicity (74.3 kcal/mol). However, in a non-polar toluene solvent, the relative Gibbs free energy of intermediate 6 decreased drastically to 20.6 kcal/mol. With the dielectric constant increasing, intermediate 6 become more stable than 2 (-6.5 kcal/mol vs. -5.3 kcal/mol) and the margin is further broadening. In short, the more polar the solvent, the more stable the ionic compound in the path II. However, the energy barrier for the H atom of the intermediate 8 binding to the I− was also increased with high solvent polarity, from 7.1 kcal/mol (Ni catalyst in dichloromethane) to 15.4 kcal/mol (Ni catalyst in dimethylformamide), and 11.2 kcal/mol (Pd catalyst in dichloromethane) to 18.8 kcal/mol (Pd catalyst in dimethylformamide), respectively. This may result in the reaction ending in an ion pair without the desired methyl acrylate being obtained. Quantitative prediction of the rate-determining step requires the accurate description of the solvent with different dielectric constants. The sophisticated implicit solvent model SMD was widely used for geometry optimizations in modeling the synthesis of the acrylic acid and its derivatives by CO2/C2H4 coupling owing to its simplicity and relatively high accuracy [41,55,59]. For some reactions with formation of strong hydrogen bonding or direct interaction between the solvent molecule and the metal center, the solvation energy could possibly be improved by including some explicit solvent molecules. Therefore, the key reaction steps including the M-O bond cleavage and the β-H elimination were further studied by inclusion of an extra solvent for both Ni-/Pd-mediated reactions, respectively. Meanwhile, the formation of intermediate 6 was also considered owing to the nature of the solvent which is important for I− detachment. The Gibbs free energy barriers (TS-1-2, TS-3-4), and the relative Gibbs free energies (intermediate 2, 6) computed by inclusion of an extra solvent molecule were included in the Supplementary Materials as Fig. S3. The energy barrier of M-O cleavage decreases with the increase of the dielectric constant of solvents in both nickel- and palladium-mediated systems. However, different from the implicit solvent models, the solvent dimethylformamide gives the lowest energy barrier for Ni-O bond cleavage than the other two solvents using the hybrid solvent model. Similarly, as the dielectric constant increase, the energy barrier for the β-H elimination decreases accordingly in both catalytic systems, which is consistent with the implicit solvent models. Likewise, the intermediate 2 and 6 are more stable with increasing of the dielectric constant of the solvent. In general, both the implicit solvation model (SMD) and the hybrid solvation model gave very similar energy barriers and the relative energies of the intermediates (Fig. 2 vs. Fig. S3). It is worth noting that the rate-determining step remains the same with/without inclusion of an extra solvent molecule. Interestingly, Kühn has shown that methyl trifluoromethanesulfonate (MeOTf) is more effective than MeI in inducing the cleavage of the M–O bond and in the liberation of acrylate [38]. They found that 0.5 equiv of MeOTf could induce the formation of methyl acrylate and obtain the moderate yields of methyl acrylate. Nevertheless, with the amount of MeOTf increasing to 1 equivalent, the yield of methyl acrylate decreased. This is because the MeOTf shows a larger dipole moment (2.86D) than dichloromethane (2.14D), leading to an increase in the polarity of the solvent. The increased polarity of the solvent facilitates the stabilization of cations, and reduces the yield of methyl acrylate. There is no doubt that dichloromethane has a significant positive effect on the yield of methyl acrylate. The highest yield of 33% was obtained by performing the reaction in dichloromethane in Rieger's experiments [37]. Therefore, dichloromethane is selected for further studies. Unless otherwise stated, the solvent of the complexes in the following parts of this work is represented as dichloromethane. MeI Assisted Acrylate Formation: The Effect of Methyl Halides. Fig. 3 shows the relative Gibbs free energies for the methyl acrylate formation assisted by different halomethanes CH3X (X = F, Cl, Br, I) over Ni-based catalysts. The optimized structures of the methyl-coordinated nickelalactones 2Ni are depicted in Fig. 4 . Obviously, the Ni-O bonds of all methyl-coordinated nickelalactones 2Ni are elongated in comparison to the original nickelalactones 1Ni . Taking methyl iodide as an example, the Ni-O bond extends from 1.915 Å in intermediate 1 to 1.976 Å in intermediate 2. The Ni-O bond lengths decrease in the order CH3F (2.024 Å) > CH3Cl (2.004 Å) > CH3Br (1.985 Å) > CH3I (1.976 Å). Moreover, the formation of methyl-coordinated nickelalactones 2Ni is exergonic by 5.3 kcal/mol in the presence of CH3I, which is endergonic for the other three methyl halides (CH3F; 20.1 kcal/mol > CH3Br; 6.1 kcal/mol > CH3Cl; 5.0 kcal/mol, in order of endergonicity) (Fig. 3). The turnover frequency (TOF) determines the efficiency of the catalytic cycle. According to the Energy Span Model developed by Kozuch and Shaik, the kinetics of a catalytic cycle are determined by the rate-determining intermediate (TDI) and the rate-determining transition states (TDTS) [60]. The TOFs were calculated to show a clear effect of methyl halides on the acrylate formation (Table S2). The CH3I electrophile gives a large value of TOF (6.5 h−1) than the other three halomethanes in the Ni-mediated systems. Therefore, methyl iodide is the best methylation agent for promoting the acrylates formation from coupling of CO2 and ethylene. Bruckmeier et al. [37] proposed that the splitting of the Ni-O bond proceeds simultaneously with weakening of the Ni-O bond due to carboxyl methylation on the one hand, and with compensation of the electron loss caused by the induced new ligand (e.g., iodo ligand) at the nickel center on the other hand. Therefore, the energy barrier of Ni-O cleavage is related to the electron-donating ability of the halide ion, in the order I− > Br− ≈ Cl− > F−. Meanwhile, the individual intermediates of the overall reaction become more stable with increasing of the electron-donating ability of halide ion. Hence, with the largest ion radius and the highest electron-donating ability, the I− is undoubtedly the most viable methylation reagent for the production of methyl acrylate [25,38–42]. Cleavage of M-O Bonds of the Metallalactone over Nickel and Palladium Catalysts. Lee et al. [42] proposed a one-step complete cleavage of the Ni-O bond by attaching a methyl group to the oxygen atom bound to nickel (tmeda-ligated nickelalactone 1), which requires an unreasonably high barrier of 58.6 kcal/mol. We focused on species bearing the 1,2-bis(dimethylphosphino)ethane (dmpe) ligand, in which the N in tmeda is replaced by P (Fig. S4 in the Supplementary Materials). The calculated activation energy of dmpe ligand for the one-step mechanism was 49.9 kcal/mol, which is slightly lower than that of tmeda ligand. Subsequently, Plessow et al. [40] considered methylation via a two-step mechanism, the M-O bond cleavage occurred after the addition of MeI on the nickelalactone 1. The addition of MeI could occur via two ways: (i) methyl electrophilic attacking to the O1 (ester sp3 O) atom adjacent to the metal center, and (ii) methyl electrophilic attack on the O2 (carboxylic sp2 O) atom (Fig. S4 in the Supplementary Materials). The corresponding energy barrier is less than 30 kcal/mol for the two-step mechanism. The intermediate 2′ and 2 are -0.9 kcal/mol and -5.3 kcal/mol relative to the reactants, indicating that Ni-O cleavage is slightly thermodynamically favorable. A stable ring-opened complex 3 could be obtained after the Ni-O bond cleavage through a transition state with a low energy barrier. This suggests that the two-step mechanism is more reliable than the one-step mechanism in terms of energy barriers [41]. We first studied four types of ligands with two methylene bridges −(CH2)2− (Scheme 2), including dmpe (E2), dppe (F2), dcpe (G2), and dtbpe (H2). The M-O cleavage barriers with these four ligands in both Ni- and Pd-mediated systems are shown in Fig. 5 . For the O1 attack mechanism, the energy barrier of M-O cleavage increased with the enhanced steric bulkiness of diphosphine ligands in both the nickel- and palladium-mediated systems, from 25.6 kcal/mol (E2 Ni) to 29.5 kcal/mol (H2 Ni), and 22.9 kcal/mol (E2 Pd) to 27.9 kcal/mol (H2 Pd), respectively. The high energy barrier is accounted for the steric hindrance imposed by the ligand which prevents the methyl iodide from approaching O1 atom. In addition, the M-O cleavage over nickel-based catalyst is more sensitive to the steric hindrance of the ligand than that over the palladium-based catalyst, which is in accordance with our previous study [55]. Based on the calculated results, Pd-based catalysis is significantly better than Ni catalysis in the O1 mechanism due to the slightly longer Pd-P bond than the Ni-P bond, which reduces the ligand steric hindrance effect [38]. Meanwhile, Iwasawa suggested that a longer M-O bond length might facilitate the cleavage of metallactones [61]. Likewise, we calculated the value of the TOFs for the production of methyl acrylate assisted by different diphosphine ligands. As shown in Tables S3 and S4, the dtbpe ligand gives the largest value of TOF (49.0 h−1 for Ni system, and 45.0 h−1 for Pd system) than the other diphosphine ligands in both the Ni- and Pd-mediated systems. The charge transfer between the methylation agents and the metal center is essential for the M-O bond cleavage in the metallalactone [62]. Therefore, the natural population analysis (NPA) was carried out to understand the effect of the methylation reagent on the electron distribution in the metallalactone 1 (Table S5). The electrophilic attack of methyl iodide on O atom can decrease the electron density of the metal atom, leading to higher NPA charge on the metal center. The methyl iodide, acted as an electron donor, provided electron to metallalactone 1 to assist the M-O bond cleavage in the metallalactone. The ligand effect on the M-O bond cleavage through the O2 attack mechanism behaves differently from the O1 attack mechanism. The energy barrier of Ni-O cleavage decreases with the increased steric bulkiness of diphosphine ligands in the nickel-mediated systems, from 21.2 kcal/mol (E2 Ni) to 20.0 kcal/mol (H2 Ni). In the Pd-mediated system, the steric hindrance of dppe ligand is larger than that of dmpe ligand, but Pd system with dppe ligand has a higher energy barrier (22.7 vs 20.8 kcal/mol). This may be due to the stronger electron-donating ability of methyl compared to phenyl. Similarly, the electron-donating ability of cyclohexyl and tert-butyl are stronger than methyl, but the energy barrier of dtbpe ligand is slightly lower than that of dcpe ligand (20.0 vs. 20.2 kcal/mol), indicating that the effects of steric hindrance also present [55]. For the O2 attack mechanism, we speculate that the M-O cleavage process on the Ni-mediated system is mainly influenced by the ligand steric hindrance instead of the ligand electronic effect, while the M-O cleavage process on the Pd-mediated system is influenced by both the steric hindrance and the electronic effect of the ligand. We then studied the M-O bond cleavage mediated by Ni-based and Pd-based catalysts, including another 12 ligands by varying the methylene bridges −(CH2)n− (Scheme 2, n = 1, 3, 4) [63]. The relative Gibbs free energies in Fig. 5 for the ligands with two methylene bridges are also included in Table 1 for comparison. The enhanced steric hindrance with increase of the ligand bite angle (P-M-P), makes the O1 attack mechanism less favorable than the O2 attack mechanism. Taking the ligands containing tert-butyl substituents in the Ni-mediated system as an example, H1−H4, the calculated barriers for the O1 attack mechanism increased in the order H1 Ni (23.9 kcal/mol) < H2 Ni (29.5 kcal/mol) < H3 Ni (30.1 kcal/mol) < H4 Ni (34.2 kcal/mol). However, the opposite trend is observed for the O2 attack mechanism, the calculated barriers decreased in the order H1 Ni (21.2 kcal/mol) > H2 Ni (20.0 kcal/mol) > H3 Ni (19.6 kcal/mol) > H4 Ni (18.6 kcal/mol). This finding suggests that the bite angle can be used as a useful descriptor in tuning the energy barriers of the M-O bond cleavage [55,63]. As it is evident from Table 1, for bisphosphonate ligands with a small bite angle, such as E1, F1, G1, H1, the O1 attack mechanism is either preferred or it is competitive with the O2 attack mechanism, while the O2 attack mechanism is preferred when ligands have a large bite angle, such as E4, F4, G4 and H4. However, in the subsequent study we found that the bite angle could only explain the trend in the calculated energy barriers for the ligand groups with the same P substituents. The comparison of the ligands between two subsets with the same methylene chain length but different steric bulkiness made the bite angle a relatively poor descriptor. In the case of ligands with the two methylene bridge -(CH2)2- in a Pd-mediated O1 attack mechanism, with very similar bite angles (F2, 86.2°; G2, 86.1°; H2, 88.3°), the calculated energy barriers increased with catalyst F2 Pd of 25.7 kcal/mol, catalyst G2 Pd of 27.6 kcal/mol, and catalyst H2 Pd of 29.5 kcal/mol, respectively. The calculations indicated that the variation of the ligand bite angle had only a minor effect on the overall catalytic reaction [55]. The different steric hindrance of these four ligands are indeed evident by analysis of the steric maps [49,50] of the nickelalactone complexes 1 (Fig. 6 ). The steric map of F2 Ni compared to H2 Ni shows a much larger space available for CH3I to approach the metal center in the O1 attack mechanism. Fey has summarized descriptors for a representative set of the ligands, which facilitates the future application of computational ligand descriptors in catalytic analysis [64]. Meanwhile, Cummins prepared a new family of cis-macrocyclic diphosphines for the Ni-catalyzed acrylates formation from CO2 and ethylene [65]. In order to explore a ligand with high catalytic efficiency for the Pd-based system, we further investigated another 11 ligands that have been explored in acrylates formation over nickel-mediated systems or in other types of reactions, including phosphine-amine L7, diphosphines (L1, L4), diphosphines with heteroatoms such as O, S, N, F (L2, L3, L5, L10 and L11), diamines L8, L9, and the chelating carbene ligand L6 (1,2-bis [N-(N’-methylimidazolium)]-methylene) (Scheme 3). Table 2 lists the energy barriers of the Pd-mediated M-O bond cleavage with 11 different ligands. Interestingly, ligand L6 gives a low energy barrier for both the O1 attack mechanism and the O2 attack mechanism (21.5 and 19.2 kcal/mol). Probably, the low energy barrier of Pd-O cleavage is due to the strong electron-donating ability and small steric hindrance of the ligand L6. As previously mentioned, the M-O cleavage process on the Pd-mediated system is influenced by both the steric hindrance and the electronic effect of the ligand. L10 and L11 are two ligands with higher electroattractive groups like Ph-NO2 and C6F5. The results show that L10 and L11 are not superior in promoting the cleavage of Pd-O bond with comparison to the dicarbene ligand L6 (Table 2). Notably, in several cases, the O1 mechanism is more suitable than the O2 mechanism for a benzene ring as a substituent on a bisphosphine ligand, perhaps depending on its high flexibility [35]. Preliminary DFT calculations of bidentate ligands in the gas phase by Lee et al. [42] showed little difference between the diamine and the diphosphine ligand with nickel as the metal center. In contrast to the one-step mechanism used in their calculations for direct Ni-O bond cleavage, there is a slight difference (within 3 kcal/mol) in the diamine and diphosphine ligand in the two-step mechanism with palladium as the metal center. The highest transition state along the two-step route is at ∼25.6 kcal/mol for tmeda ligand, but it is slightly lower (∼22.7 kcal/mol) for dmpe ligand. Therefore, the diphosphine ligand is superior to the diamine ligand in the acrylates formation over Pd-based system. Elimination of β-H over Nickel and Palladium Catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the energy barrier of β-H elimination for different ligands (E2, dmpe; F2, dppe; G2, dcpe; H2, dtbpe, Scheme 2 ) in both the Ni- and Pd-mediated systems. The energy barrier of β-H elimination decreases with increase of the electron-donating ability of the diphosphine ligands in the Pd- and Ni-mediated systems, from 18.9 kcal/mol (F2 Pd) to 12.5 kcal/mol (G2 Pd), and 10.0 kcal/mol (F2 Ni) to 2.9 kcal/mol (G2 Ni), respectively. The electron-donating ability of a given substituents on bisphosphine ligands increases in the following order: phenyl < methyl < tert-butyl < cyclohexyl [55,59]. The corresponding energy barrier of β-H elimination is inversely proportional to the electron-donating ability of ligands. Meanwhile, the energy barrier of β-H elimination in the Ni-mediated system is lower than that of the Pd-mediated system for all given ligands. Perhaps, this is because the longer Pd-C bond compared to Ni-C bond in 3 results in a longer distance for β-H transfer to the metal center. We also calculated the energy barrier of β-H elimination for path II. The complete free energy profiles of Ni- and Pd-mediated systems are displayed in Fig. S5 and Fig. S6 in the Supplementary Materials, respectively. However, we found that there is no correlation between the steric hindrance or electronic effects of the ligands and the calculated energy barriers of β-H elimination in the Ni-mediated system. Notably, the dppe ligand is slightly more favorable than the other ligands in the β-H elimination process (11.4 kcal/mol), which is approached to the energy barrier of β-H elimination in path I (10 kcal/mol) in the Ni-mediated system. Interestingly, Guo et al. [41] found significant effects of ligands on the side reactions, which compete with the main reactions and are detrimental to the formation of methyl acrylate by examining the effects of dppe, dppp, and dppb ligands. The energy barrier of β-H elimination also decreases with the increase of the electron-donating ability of the diphosphine ligands in the Pd-mediated system (Fig. S6 in the Supplementary Materials), from 13.1 kcal/mol (F2 Pd) to 9.7 kcal/mol (G2 Pd). However, the energy barrier of β-H elimination in path II is lower than that of the path I for the given ligand in the Pd-mediated system, and the difference in energy barrier is larger than 4 kcal/mol for all ligands except for the dcpe ligand. This demonstrates the superiority of the ligand series containing cyclohexyl substituents in the Pd-mediated system. Furthermore, the energy barrier of β-H elimination is lower than that of the Ni-O bond cleavage in the Ni-mediated system, while in the palladium system the energy barriers of the two key steps are very close. We conducted a more extensive exploration of the behavior of cyclohexyl ligands in the Pd-mediated system, to elucidate the effect of steric hindrance on the β-H elimination. As shown in Table 3 , the energy barrier for β-H elimination decreased with the increase of the steric hindrance for the ligands with four methylene bridges, from 17.4 kcal/mol (G1 Pd) to 10.7 kcal/mol (G3 Pd). Meanwhile, from a geometrical point of view, we observe a good correlation between the energy barrier of β-H elimination and the M-I distance, from 2.780 to 2.819 Å. Of course, this direct correlation is consistent with the increased steric hindrance from the ligands, which prevents the I− from optimally approaching the Pd center. Interestingly, Kühn found that despite close similarities of the crystal structures of the metallalactones with diphosphine ligands, there were irregularities in their performance of β-H elimination in the presence of CH3I [42]. Meanwhile, Liang et al. [66] found that Ni fragments with spatially hindered PNP pincer ligands form stabilized bonds with alkyl esters, which are inert to β-H elimination, and that the pincer ligands will block the rotation of the β-H atom toward the metal center. Therefore, it is not surprising that the energy barrier of β-H elimination for G4 ligand was 13.2 kcal/mol, which was higher than that for G3 ligand (10.7 kcal/mol). Based on the analysis above, since the dcpp ligand have a strong electron-donating ability and large steric hindrance, it cannot prevent the rotation of β-H to the metal center and it is undoubtedly the most preferred options for the β-H elimination process in the Pd-mediated system. 4 Conclusions The formation of methyl acrylate from CO2 and ethylene in the presence of MeI was systematically investigated by means of DFT calculations. A series of bidentate ligands with different electronic properties and steric hindrance were studied to elucidate the different catalytic properties of Ni- and Pd-mediated systems. The polarity of the solvent is of high importance for the production of methyl acrylate. High polarity solvents can effectively promote the M-O bond cleavage and the β-H elimination of the reaction, while the energy barriers are inhibitive in the gas phase or in low-polar solvents. Meanwhile, the high-polar solvents can further stabilize the ion pairs as compared to the gas phase and low-polar solvents. The energy barrier for Ni-O bond cleavage as well as the stability of all the reaction intermediate is related to the electron-donating ability of the corresponding halogen. The I− , with the largest ion radius and the highest electron-donating ability, is undoubtedly the most viable methylation reagent for the production of methyl acrylate. The energy barrier of M-O bond cleavage increases with the enhancement of the steric bulkiness in the O1 attack mechanism, while the corresponding O2 mechanism shows the opposite trend in the Pd- and Ni-mediated systems. In general, the O2 attack mechanism is more preferred than the O1 attack mechanism in terms of energy barriers. In the subsequent β-H elimination process, the energy barrier is greatly affected by the electron-donating ability. In the Pd-mediated system, the catalytic efficiency of the diamine ligand is generally lower than that of the diphosphine ligand, which may be related to their coordination properties. Due to the large steric hindrance and the excellent electron-donating ability, the ligand G3 (dcpp) exhibits relatively good performance for palladium-catalyzed acrylates formation with relatively low energy barriers for both reactions including Pd-O bond cleavage and β-H elimination. coredata.dc:description: In this work, two methylation reaction pathways were investigated to explore the role of solvent and I− on the formation of methyl acrylate from coupling of CO2 and ethylene catalyzed by nickel and palladium catalysts in the presence of MeI. The stabilization of non-productive intermediates is inhibited in the gas phase as well as in low-polar solvents, which explains the requirement of high excess of MeI to obtain high yields of methyl acrylate. The energy barrier for M-O bond cleavage as well as the stability of the overall reaction intermediates is consistent with the corresponding halogen electron-donating ability. The different catalytic behaviors of various bidentate ligands on Ni- and Pd-based catalysts were systematically investigated, mainly including dmpe(1,2-bis(dimethylphosphino)ethane), tmeda(tetramethylethylenediamine), dppe(1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane), dcpe(1,2-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)ethane) and dtbpe(1,2-bis(di-tert-butylphosphino)ethane). The energy barrier of M-O bond cleavage increases with the enhancement of ligand steric hindrance in the O1 (ester sp3 O atom) attack mechanism, while the corresponding O2 (carboxylic sp2 O atom) attack mechanism shows an opposite trend. The energy barrier of β-H elimination in both catalytic systems is strongly related to the electron-donating ability of the diphosphine ligand substituents. The dcpp(1,3-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)propane) ligand shows relatively good performance for β-H elimination among all the investigated ligands in Pd-mediated system. In general, diphosphine ligands are superior to diamine ligands in Pd-mediated system in terms of efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding the acrylates formation from CO2 and ethylene over Ni- and Pd-based catalysts: A DFT study on the effects of solvents, methyl halides, and ligands
